I have yet to try a salad or sandwich here because the lines are always long, but their hot bar is pretty good and the line is short or nonexistent.  Standard for me is 1/2 chicken with two sides - it's about $9 and is enough for lunch and dinner.  When I've gone their steamed vegetables have been consistently a little understeamed, but I eat early, so maybe they're just trying to accommodate the veggies sitting out in the hot tray.  Bread is free, which is both amazing and dangerous.  I totally didn't realize it was free the first time I went.
author: KT R.

description:
for a $4.95 lunch you can't really complain.

solid salad choices and pretty quick. the tofu is awesome although pretty inconsistent, sometimes it's soggy, sometimes not spicy and sometimes its firm, but generally it's good.

my typical order is a small mixed greens salad, with tofu, roasted beets, mushrooms and garbanzo beans with sesame soy dressing (the lime vinaigrette is good too). sometimes i'll add avocado or strawberries.

avoid the short (height) salad makers, they cannot reach the items in the back row and as a result that topping will be skimped on. also make sure you speak very clearly or they will misunderstand what topping you want. last time i was there i had to say "roasted beets" 4 times, and she still thought i was saying red peppers. tell them you want light dressing unless you want your salad to be drenched. some of the salad makers give you lots of toppings some skimp...good luck, hope you get a good one!

don't forget to pick up your free foccacia bread on the way out. and don't forget to pay, they have a security guard standing by the door to prevent theft.
author: Elaine S.

description: Did I just spend $8-plus on a sausage omelette, hash browns, and a croissant? D'OH!
author: Maximillian M.

description: I absolutely love Focaccia--my new favorite place for a quick lunch in SF! So far, I have only ordered sandwiches--the bread is fresh and the sandwiches are nicely toasted. These sandwiches are huge, so they can easily be split between 2 people. At 6.95 per sandwich (and 1/2 sandwiches are also available) this place is less expensive (and 1000 times better) than the cafeteria provided on site at my work. All sandwiches are made to order, and my favorite combination so far has been the prosciutto with fresh mozzarella and the pesto mayonnaise on the wheat focaccia bread. The cookies are also delicious! Haven't had the salad there but will have to try it soon. All the ingredients are fresh and the portions are generous. If you haven't checked this place out soon, you should! It's SOOO good!
author: Amanda S.

description: I come by here early and it's great that their open and ready to serve. I grab a egg & cheese in a croissant for a solid breakfast.
author: Scott C.

description: I come here for sandwiches at lunch. Come before 12 (even 11:50) is good to beat the lunch rush. The Focaccia bread is the best, hands down. After that, feel free to customize your sandwich as you see fit!
author: Srikanth K.

description: Being a fan of the one on Sacramento St., I was surprised and happy to see one closer to my office. Their salads are good, the hot meals are great, and their sandwiches are excellent. I'd give them another star if they are able to stay stocked up on focaccia bread by the time I get there. Their name is Focaccia Market, after all.
author: LM M.

description:
sandwiches are huge and the other half is still good the next day.

try: toasted wheat foccacia bread with capered mayo, smoked salmon, tomato, and cucumber. it's mine and kat m's jam. (although some days i gotta change it up to tuna cuz you know, that salmon feels oily if you eat too much)
author: Melanie C.

description: The best part about this place is that it's close (read across the courtyard from) my office and quick.  They make salads and sandwiches to order at reasonable prices.  The only problem is that everyone seems to know about this place even though it only opened recently so the lines are pretty long during peek lunch hours.  There is the option of getting a pre-made salads though and some of those are pretty good too.  They also have hot food with different options daily and there's usually no line for that for some reason even though the food is pretty good (although generally less healthy/light than the salad).  One thing though - despite their name, their focaccia is not so great.  I mean it's free so you can't complain but it needs some salt or rosemary or something.  (They also misspelled ciabatta on their menu, which I find annoying.)
author: barbara b.

description: Fresh good food and very low prices for what you get. Only problem is the staff. Guy who made my salad didn't know almonds from walnuts. Guy who made my sandwich didn't know what pastrami was. I had to point it out to them in both cases. It's as if Focaccia hires day laborer off the corner and puts them in chef jackets and behind the counter with 5 minutes of training. For such an otherwise efficient and beautiful establishment, the staff quality really stands out.
author: Andy H.

description: YUM! HUGE lines but worth it! I am reviewing the salads (which I normally don't eat).
author: Katrina H.

description:
After all these months, I am still getting the off-the-shelf prepared Greek salad (and could not begin to count how many I have bought), but once again - the olives have pits.  All (but one) of the other MANY times olives are pit-less, but this is the second time I bit into a pit unexpectedly, ouch (says my tooth).  The first time this happened I spoke to the manager about this, and she said that they got the wrong delivery - olives with pits -  and they were just using them up.  However, there is never any warning that your usual salad w/out pits now has them (some even fall out of the olive itself and appear randomly after biting into what seems like just a clump of lettuce.  NOT GOOD.  I had asked if they would put a label on the salad "olives contain pits" so the customers who regularly buy the salad expecting no pits could be prepared, but apparently my suggestion was lost.  
I still love this place but am only giving 2 stars this time because of what seems to be lack of quality control and caring.
author: gail c.

description: People at work had good things to say about focaccia but I'd never tried it. It's set away from the street, so I could never even FIND it. But yesterday I did, and I went in. You stand in line for either a sandwich or a salad, or you can get premade ones from the wall. The food seems to be of very good quality. I had a whole wheat bread, sun dried tomato spread, brie and chicken breast sandwich with cucumbers, lettuce and tomato for under $8. About par for the financial district, but of course too pricey for me to eat every day. LUCKILY, the sandwiches are good size and filling, and since I've had a small appetite lately, half served me for a meal, bringing the price down to under $4! You can also buy just half a sandwich but it ends up being $5 something, so buying a whole and saving the other half is cheaper. Here's the bad thing about this place - it's SLOW. I came in after 1:30, well after the rush. The premade stuff was all gone, so I went to the sandwich line. There were only 2 or 3 people in front of me, but it took FOREVER. So slow. A long line began to form behind me. The salad line was also long. Once I gave my sandwich preferences, he offered to toast it, so I said sure. Kinda a big mistake. It was tasty toasted, but it once again took forever. Other people's sandwiches went in and out of the oven, and mine still was toasting. The shift changed, the new guy checked my sandwich and left it toasting. There were a bunch of us now waiting for our toasted sandwiches. Pretty much it took up about all of my 30 min lunch break to get my sandwich, leaving me little time to eat it. Imagine if i'd come during the lunch rush!! it must take an unimaginable time! Still, if you have plenty of time, but don't want a sit down place, come here. It tasted good, there's so many choices and combinations, it won't get boring, although sometimes I like to see what combos the chefs come up with instead of making up my own. A-Ok. Ps, some people wrote the workers here are rude. They were neither rude nor friendly, just neutral, which is fine with me.
author: Merredith L.

description: I went to focaccia a couple of weeks ago after not having been in years.  I used to come here all the time because it was close to my old office.  I was so excited to have a focaccia sandwich.  I always used to get a veggie sandwich on whole wheat bread with brie and lots of veggies.  I was there early and there was no one else in line.  The sandwich guy clearly saw me, but still made me wait over 5 minutes before even acknowledging my presence.  He did not say hello.  He did not ask me what I wanted.  Instead he stared at me and just sort of nodded his head.  I asked for a veggie sandwich with brie.  He said, no brie.  I said ok, how about muenster and provolone.  He didn't say a word, but he rolled his eyes several times at me.  I have no idea why.  He seemed annoyed at everything I asked for.  I had forgotten to ask for balsamic, so I asked to add it after he'd put the veggies on.  This really annoyed him.  When he was finished making my sandwich, he sort of threw it on the counter.  I asked him his name.  He said it was Luis.  Then when I went to pay, he'd charged me for a regular sandwich with extra cheese, even though I had no meat.  They never used to do that!  I wish I'd chosen to go to Oasis around the corner instead.  Even when I haven't been there in years, Mohammed still recognizes me and remembers my order.  Customer service has declined significantly at focaccia.  I don't think I'll be back.
author: Erin D.

description: for phone service review only.  one word BAD.  this location needs to relearn customer service and phone manner.  more than once we have called to ask a question and they are always rude and you can't even finish your sentence.  i understand you may not be the right person to ask but at least hear the question and maybe be helpful and direct me to the right area.  why would i want to be your customer if you don't seem like you want our business.
author: Food Is L.

description: Hit or miss, hit or miss.  Food quality is rather good, yet I have only ever done the salad bit, so I can't speak the to rest of the culinary magic.  Here is what I dig,  Love the spicy tofu, dig that you can have multi weed salads and they have rather good dressings.  Here is what chaps my ass to no end and my work buddy John is on the same page.  I swear to god some of the salad ladies can't get the salad in the container to save their life and it sends me over the edge, I swear to god.  I can't handle it.  And of course it is the good stuff to that ends up on the counter.  Holy Jesus.  And I have to call a spade a spade, how hard is it to get the salad into the bowl and not drop a 1/3 on the counter.  I will have to take a break for like a week at a time, as I get soooooo infuriated.  But, I always go back and will just wait for a different salad prep girl.  Have you had this problem? Ah it is the worst.  Silver lining it is good, healthy and open till 2:30.  Go, it is a food salad.
author: Nicole F.

description: great quality food and quick service. how can you go wrong? more affordable on-site prepared, made-to-order salads than mixt greens to boot, i highly recommend.
author: Torrpedo T.
